Prof. Wirth’s Oberon RISC in Python¶

This is a simple eumulator for the RISC cpu developed by Prof. Wirth for the Oberon OS (and compiler.)

class oberon.risc.ByteAddressed32BitRAM[source]¶

Imitate a RAM that is addressed per-byte, reads and writes four-byte words by default, and can be accessed per-byte if desired.

get(addr)[source]¶

Return the word at addr, which must be a multiple of 4.

get_byte(addr)[source]¶

Return the byte at addr.

put(addr, word)[source]¶

Write the word to addr, which must be a multiple of 4.

put_byte(addr, byte)[source]¶

Write the byte to addr.

class oberon.risc.RISC(ram, PC=0)[source]¶

The RISC emulator.

Written as a class rather than a single (large) function mostly so that the intermediate state and stages could be accessible to introspection.

Arithmetic_Logical_Unit()[source]¶

branch_instruction()[source]¶

Perform a branch instruction by updating pcnext to take effect in the next cycle.

control_unit()[source]¶

The RISC unit has three very simple kinds of instructions, indicated by the two higest bits of an instruction.

if p:
  if q:
    branch instruction...
  else:
    ram instruction...
else:
  register instruction...
cycle()[source]¶

Run a single instruction-processing cycle.

This is the main interface to the emulator. Call it repeatedly to run the computer.

what_are_we_up_to()[source]¶

This is a long-winded way to figure out which operation an instruction specifies. Rather than a long if-elif-else statement we set all flags every cycle. The format of the code should make it easy to see that only one flag will be True for a given set of {(p, op), q, u}.

class oberon.risc.binary_addressing_mixin[source]¶

A mixin to allow an int or long to be addressed bit-wise.

Single index gives a boolean, two gives a new int (n >= 0) of that width.

You can use the following:

n[i]    single index
n[j:i]  slice
n[j, i] two-tuple

n[i] gives a bool while n[j:i] gives a new number created from the j - i bits beginning with the bit at i and including bits to the left (more significant.)

For example (see blong below):

>>> b = blong(23)
>>> bin(b)
'0b10111'
>>> b[3]
False
>>> b[0]
True
>>> b[4:2]
1L
class oberon.risc.blong[source]¶

A long that can be read bit-wise. See binary_addressing_mixin.
